input:
######################## number of models # Number of models for which details are described in this input file 2 ######################## restart # Restart from previous (pickled) population? False
######################## epsilon schedule # Automatic epsilon schedule. Provide a vector of final epsilons and the alpha (defaults to 0.9)
# OR # Series of epsilons. (Whitespace delimited list) # Multiple epsilon schedules can be specified by giving additional vectors enclosed in , etc # NOTE: the parser always reads them in order and ignores the tag value
380 370 360 340 300 250 150 100 90 70 50 30
######################## particles 100
######################## beta # Beta is the number of times to simulate each sampled parameter set. # This is only applicable for models simulated using Gillespie and SDE 1
######################## dt # Internal timestep for solver. # Make this small for a stiff model. 0.01
######################## perturbation kernels : OPTIONAL (default uniform) # The pertubation kernels are computed with respect to the previous parameter distribution # Currently uniform and normal are implemented uniform
######################## model kernel : OPTIONAL (default 0.7) # Probability of perturbing the sampled model (ignored when modelnumber = 1) 0.7
######################## ODE solver control : OPTIONAL # rtol and atol can be specified here. If the model is stiff then making these small might help the simulation to run 1e-1 1e-1
######################## User-supplied data
# times: For ABC SMC, times must be a whitespace delimited list # In simulation mode these are the timepoints for which the simulations will be output 0 2 5 10 20 40
# variables: For ABC SMC, whitespace delimited lists of concentrations (ODE or SDE) or molecule numbers (Gillespie) # Denote your data via tags or or etc. # The tags are ignored and the data read in order # For simulation these data are ignored # See fitting instruction below if the dimensionality of your data sets differ from the dimensionality of your model
9.03 7.03 34.49 23.71 9.03 7.9 3.78 4.77 34.49 20.26 6.67 5.1 3.29 3.78 30.66 34.49 7.41 4.85 3.34 2.75 24.31 34.49 5.09 3.91 5.04 6.72 61.72 45.93 16.96 6.04
######################## Models
model1 model1.xml
# type: the method used to simulate your model. ODE, SDE or Gillespie. ODE
# Fitting information. # If fit is None, all species in the model are fitted to the data in the order they are listed in the model. # Otherwise, give a whitespace delimited list of fitting instrictions the same length as the dimensions of your data. # Use speciesN to denote the Nth species in your model. Simple arithmetic operations can be performed on these. # For example, to fit the sum of the first two species in the model to your first variable, write fit: species1+species2 species13/100 species13/100 species13/100 species13/100 species13/100
# Priors on initial conditions and parameters: # one of # constant, value # normal, mean, variance # uniform, lower, upper # lognormal, mean, variance
constant 1000.0 constant 0.0 constant 500.0 constant 0.0 constant 1200.0 constant 0.0 constant 1200.0 constant 1500.0 constant 0.0 constant 3000.0 constant 0.0 constant 10000.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0 constant 1000.0 constant 0.0 constant 1000.0 constant 0.0 constant 1200.0 constant 1500.0 constant 0.0 constant 2400.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0
constant 1 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4 lognormal 1.97 0.64 lognormal 8.6 0.4
model2 model2.xml
# type: the method used to simulate your model. ODE, SDE or Gillespie. ODE
# Fitting information. # If fit is None, all species in the model are fitted to the data in the order they are listed in the model. # Otherwise, give a whitespace delimited list of fitting instrictions the same length as the dimensions of your data. # Use speciesN to denote the Nth species in your model. Simple arithmetic operations can be performed on these. # For example, to fit the sum of the first two species in the model to your first variable, write fit: species1+species2 species13/100 species13/100 species13/100 species13/100 species13/100
# Priors on initial conditions and parameters: # one of # constant, value # normal, mean, variance # uniform, lower, upper # lognormal, mean, variance
constant 0.0 constant 0.0 constant 500.0 constant 0.0 constant 1200.0 constant 0.0 constant 1200.0 constant 1500.0 constant 0.0 constant 3000.0 constant 0.0 constant 10000.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0 constant 1000.0 constant 0.0 constant 1000.0 constant 0.0 constant 1200.0 constant 1500.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0 constant 1200.0 constant 2400.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0 constant 0.0
